titleStmt.title: How the old Mountains drip with Sunset

publicationStmt.p: The Poems of Emily Dickinson, Johnson, 1955

lg.l: How the old Mountains drip with Sunset
How the Hemlocks burn --
How the Dun Brake is draped in Cinder
By the Setting Sun -- After --By the Setting Sun -- After -- By the Wizard Sun
How the old Steeples hand the Scarlet
Till the Ball is full --
Have I the lip of the Flamingo
That I dare to tell?
Then, how the Fire ebbs like Billows --
Touching all the Grass
With a departing -- Sapphire -- feature --
As a Duchess passed --
How a small Dusk crawls on the Village
Till the Houses blot
And the odd Flambeau, no men carry
Glimmer on the Street --
How it is Night -- in Nest and Kennel --
And where was the Wood --
Acres of Masts are standing next to --Acres of Masts are standing next to -- Just a Dome of Abyss is nodding Untonodding Unto Bowing
Into Solitude --
These are the Fashions -- baffled --Fashions -- baffled -- Visions flitted Guido --
Titian -- never told --
Domenichino dropped his pencil --
Powerless to unfold --Powerless to unfold -- Paralyzed, with Gold --
